p.s: The article Hope of escape lost in translation, written by Zia Haider Rahman published in the Sunday Times on 17th December 2016, is about immigrants not learning englischEnglish because of translation and interpreting services.
The text is structured in four paragraphs and is up to date.
It is informative, because the author wants to inform the reader of the problem of language and interpreting services and uses facts to prove her statement.
She tells the reader for example that more than Â£100mmillion was spent in the past year on translating and interpreting for British residents who don't speak English (ll. 1-2).

She also introduces the reader to her bangladeshiBangladeshi background and writes how hard it is to come from the bottom of educational achievement and a place of drug abuse, crime and gang violence (ll. 7-10).
That also is a part of the argumentative side of her text.
She argues that translating and interpreting services do not help immigrants to integrate into another culture because they do not learn the language of the country (ll. 3-4).
She names the danger of the East End, wichwhich is just like the place they come from and says that it is very hard not to be absorbed there because Britain does not help you integrate (ll. 11-13).
She weakens the argument that we should celebrate our diversity, that it does not help that you are diffrentdifferent if you can notcannot take care of yourself (ll. 18-20).
She does not support this way of handling the problem especially in school (ll. 14-17).
She supports her argument with an example of her own time in school, where her teachers did not acknowledge her racial diffrencedifference but she learned to speak englishEnglish (ll. 14-16).
The text is also appelling because she tries to convince the reader of her opinion and asks the govermentgovernment to make English compulsory for all citizens (l. 21).
She encourages public figures to say something about the problem.

The text is written for everybody who speaks englishEnglish and is interested in immigration and thinks that it helps to translate everything but especially for people who have the influence to change something about it.
The tone is serious and formal but also relaxed.
That is supported by stylistic devices like the metaphor in l. 19.
The author writes that [...] you don't learn to stand on your own two feet if somebody is holding you up.
That shows symbolic that you have to learn how to take care of yourself in a foreign country and that you can notcannot do that if somebody is always helping you.
Another stylistic device is three times my parents of the sentence beginning (ll. 10-14).
This anaphoanaphora shows how lucky the author was and that she just integrated that well because of her parents.
Others who do not get as much support from their parents are not as lucky.
Also the Hyperbonhyperbole in line 7-10 show how hard the life in BengladeshiBangladesh is.
